The First Wives Club is a good-humored but vaguely sadistic revenge picture billed as a madcap empowerment seminar. But madcap and zany? No way. For years, actresses have been complaining that strong roles for women  are limited--if not absent--in Hollywood. I couldn't agree more, but the  dearth is by no means aided by the dumber than dumb rampage of Brenda,  Elise, and Annie (Bette Midler, Goldie Hawn, and Diane Keaton).
If  white men can't jump, white chicks can't dance, and try as it might to be  hip and topical, The First Wives' Club instead becomes Waiting to Exhale  for white, middle-aged, housefraus. And these three ain't shoopin' no-how.  This movie's big-budget gets major mileage on small inspiration.

I have absolutely adored this movie on so many levels since it came out and was happy to see it again on Prime. These three actresses have great chemistry and put it to good use in this story. Here they are, friends since college, now 40 something, their husbands have all replaced them with 20 somethings... Sound familiar? Anyone??  More to the point, one of our ladies took a dignified morning stroll off her penthouse balcony so this isn't just a bit of silly whining. That's the beginning, when there were four of them. Obviously these well educated, gifted, beautiful, sassy, imaginative, caring, loving...  New York women must do SOMETHING not only for themselves but other women as well. First order, resources; they decide to tactfully enlist the sponsorship of their ex's... after all, they supported and loved these men in their rise to wealth and fame so they approach their mission as any business transaction. From my experience, these transactions appeared  generally like any hostile takeover... Take it all, show no emotion, no mercy and most of all, just have FUN with it!. Boy, did they have fun! But, hey guys, what's that old nugget? Karma's a b**** or payback, something like that. The guys got to continue working in some capacity, fair enough. They needed the money to keep paying their First Wives!

Diane Keaton, Bette Midler and Goldie Hawn nailed their roles, made us laugh, cry, sing and maybe feel a little lighter even twenty years after the making of this film. Through their characters we see once again women standing up, taking back their power, overcoming obstacles and moving forward. It was excellent FUN watching them perform this on such a grand scale comedy. My supportive crazy theatrical friends and I were so inspired when this movie came out, we had a large celebratory divorce party on a yacht and sang "You Don't Own Me" then I happily threw my ring overboard! I felt fabulous, dahling!!  Life imitates art!? lol...

I loved The First Wives Club years ago when it first came out and I still love it.  I had some rare downtime over the weekend and decided to watch this movie again. This is one of those movies that will make you laugh, cry, get angry and be happy.  I loved that the friendship between Bette, Goldie and Dianne re-kindled, even though it was due to a tragic reason.  These three women are so different from each other, but they had a special bond that didn't diminish due to the time that had passed.  I hate that Cynthia didn't reach out to her friends before doing the unthinkable - but it was sweet that she mailed each of them a letter before to prove that they were always on her mind. This definitely got me to thinking about my friendship than span over 40 years - Friends forever!

I especially loved the song and dance at the end of the movie - I watched them sashay all the way down that street.  Awesome movie!

Unfortunately, First Wives Club is not a "clean" movie. I actually watch it with a ClearPlay filter.

There are some sexual references, such as a girl tells her mother and father she is a lesbian; a man is seen in a dressing gown, his chest is seen; three women go to a gay club; all three "wives" husbands left them for a younger woman, whom they are having affairs with.

The only violence shown is a woman steps onto a step preparing to jump off a building, but then they cut the scene away; a woman hits another woman with a form baton for "therapy"; three women slap each other in turn.

There are quite a few instances of minor curse words used throughout the movie and a woman is seen drinking and smoking at the beginning of the film and one woman drinks throughout the film.

The movie is about four college friends who lost touch with each other, until one of them commits suicide because her husband left her for a younger woman, and so kills herself because of loneliness.  The other three reunite after their friends funeral only to discover their lives aren't much better.  Brenda is divorced, left for a younger woman, depressed, and struggling financially. Elise, whose husband also left her for a younger woman, is now an aging alcoholic movie actress who has become a plastic-surgery addict to keep her career afloat. Annie, meanwhile, is separated, suffering extreme self-esteem issues, and going through therapy with her husband, until she finds out that he wants a divorce and is having an affair with their therapist  With the help of Annie's daughter, Brenda's Uncle Carmine who has Maufia connections, and Elise's money, they form the First Wives Club.  They starts out just wanting revenge, but then decide that it would make them no better than their husbands. So when they find out that Brenda's husband is guilty of income tax fraud, Elise's husband is dating a minor, and Annie's husband's business partners want to sell their shares, and so with the help of Elise, Annie buys them out - they use these situations to push their men into funding their new nonprofit organization dedicated to aiding abused women, in memory of their college friend Cynthia.

Overall, I like the movie. It has a lot of funny parts, but I would not watch it without some kind of filter.

Director Hugh Wilson's colorful and stylish 1996 comedy, based on a raunchier novel by the late Olivia Goldsmith(who cameos as a mourner at a funeral), greets us with Roy Liechtenstein-like art by Charles Beal, portraying women frequently engaged in various activities as Dionne Warwick sings her rendering of the '60s classic, "Wives and Lovers".
 Soon, the graphics fade, and Diane Keaton's repressed, guilt-ridden housewife, Annie Paradis, begins her narration with memories of her 1969 graduation from Middlebury College with her three best friends, who, via the brilliant casting of Ilene Starger, are played by actresses who bear incredibly strong resemblances to their middle-aged counterparts.
 The young graduates, including Annie(Adria Tenor), Brenda Murelli(Michele Brilliant), Elise Elliot(Dina Spybey) are gifted with sets of pearls by Valedictorian Cynthia Swann(Julihera DeStefano). Looking forward to bright futures, they toast the moment with champagne in paper cups as they pose for a snapshot of themselves. Indeed, the morning of life shines brilliantly for these four musketeers!
 But Life's midday(fast-forwarding to the '90s), is doleful. A now more mature Cynthia(Stockard Channing), is carrying another drink in hand, and giving her pearls to her maid, Theresa(Aida Linares) before making a fateful decision in response to her ex-husband's (James Naughton) jilting her for another woman(Heather Locklear).
 We find Annie being chided by her grown daughter, Chris(Jennifer Dundas), for being  a "doormat" to her estranged husband,Aaron(Stephen Collins), but lauded by her posessive mother, Catherine(Eileen Heckart) for the apparent reconciliation.
 Brenda(Bette Midler, snide, wisecracking, and playing for laughs as always)is busy coaxing her son Jason(Ari Greenberg) to study his Hebrew for his upcoming Bar Mitzphah, the only thing her estranged husband Morty(Dan Hedaya), who left her for a young woman who worked at his electronics store named Shelly Stewart(a churlish and manipulative Sarah Jessica Parker), is willing to pay for.
 We find the pampered, overindulgent actress, Elise(Goldie Hawn) in the chair of plastic surgeon Morris Packman(Rob Reiner) demanding yet another procedure despite
his claim that she has had too many.
 All three, who failed to keep in touch after graduation, as they had promised, share a jarring experience at the news of Cynthia's suicide. Reuniting at her funeral, they subsequently dine at at restaurant at Elise's invitation, and the presence of the empty chair at the table for four is palpable.
 Annie is the only one who cannot  publicly come to terms with the failure of her marriage, and will need to dismiss the psychobabble imposed on her by her therapist, Dr. Leslie Rosen (Marcia Gay Harden in the familar role of the femme fatale), whom both she and Aaron are seeing, but not quite for the same reasons, and accept the reality of her situation instead of trying to cling to an unrealistically postive view of things. Soon the reality will be jarringly and unavoidably harsh.
 In the company of Duarto Feliz(Bronson Pinchot), the interior decorator for whom she works, Brenda has an unpleasant run-in with Morty and Shelly at a women's clothing store, and Elyse learns her divorce settlement will include her having to pay her ex-husband Bill(Victor Garber)alimony, although she was the one who taught him the business, and he is in actuality, indebted to her. She also learns that her attempt to look younger has not paid off when Director Brett Artounian(Timothy Olyphant) hires her for the part of the older lead in his film when she'd hoped for the part of the younger woman, a role which will go to Bill's bimbo lover, Phoebe LaVelle(Elizabeth Berkley) who ultimately could be Bill's ruin.
 The recipience of the three suicide notes from Cynthia spurs Annie into action. The three women meet, and discuss how best to deal with their situation in what becomes the first meeting of the First Wives Club.
 Forging alliances with Elyse's friend, Gunilla Garson Goldberg(the incomparable Maggie Smith), the highly influential Queen of New York Society, and gaining support from Duarto, Chris, and Brenda's Sicillian Uncle Carmine(Phillip Bosco), the last of whom will be the muscle behind their operation,they carry out an agenda which will not only result in justice on behalf of themselves, but, amid some trepidation and strife,will eventually benefit society at large as well.
 Along for the ride are Kate Burton, Walter Bobbie, Debra Monk, and Jennifer Lam in cameo roles, as are Ed Koch, Gloria Steinem,Kathie Lee Gifford, and Ivana Trump, who utters the film's most famous line, "Don't get mad. Get everything!"
 This is a cleverly crafted production that reveals the strength and renewal of forgotten abilities by the unity of three  friends in the midst of a crisis, who ultmately channel their powers towards the greater good. Three women reunited dressed in mourning will celebrate a victory clad in various shades of off-white, each sporting their precious pearls as a way to figuratively keep Cynthia near.
  The formerly timid Annie recounts her fear at having to sing for Cynthia on her 21st birthday, along with Brenda and Elyse. But ultimately these women sing not only for the fallen Cynthia, but also for themselves and for their triumph over adversity that their unity has created.

Here's the premise: after the suicide of a close college friend (Stockard Channing), three ex-wives (played by Goldie Hawn, Bette Midler and Diane Keaton) maneuver the destruction of their ex-husbands' careers and lives. Sounds like a great `I Am Woman' sicko-revenge trip, right? It actually is, for the most part - it's just that the film (based on Olivia Goldsmith's novel) becomes a bit excessive with its over-dramatization, far-fetched kookiness and stereotypical hoopla. The whole thing turns into a `How can we outwit these miserable men and take all their money and be really clever and coy about it the whole while' kind of story. After years of helping their husbands build hugely successful businesses, the three women are callously dumped for younger, sexier "trophy wives." What I don't understand is why these smart, business-minded, middle-aged women bothered with their husbands in the first place, or why they expel all this narcissistic energy in dealing with them! (For Christ's sake ladies, let this film be an example, learn early that all men are good for nothing!) Oddly enough, Diane Keaton's on-screen daughter is the happiest person in the film, not to mention the least dysfunctional, and she's a lesbian!  The whole movie comes off like a cross between 9 To 5 and The War Of the Roses, though nowhere near as sick and deranged as the latter - The First Wives Club points out everything in light-hearted raillery. Bette Midler is excellent as Brenda, the wife of an electronics-emporium magnate, and Goldie Hawn, as good as always, plays Elise Elliot, an aging movie-star who can't get any roles -- an important issue in Hollywood right now (key word being `Hollywood'). Being a member of Joe Blow's Average America, its hard to feel really sympathetic for the character (or the real issue). So an actress can't pull down that typical 3 or 4 million any more -deal with it, get a job at Pizza Hut, or shut the hell up! Diane Keaton, on the other hand, seems a little out of place in such a `free and easy' production, though her performance is plenty good, as is Sarah Jessica Parker's as Shelly. There are also some delightful little cameos from Heather Lockear; Jon Stewart, Ivana Trump, Kathie Lee Gifford, James Naughton, Rob Reiner and Elizabeth Berkley.

The three get back together after her funeral and discover that while the years have affected them differently they have all experienced the same woes when their husbands, who they were there to support in their early, lean years, achieved success, and all left them for younger women.

Diane Keaton, perhaps the weakest of them all, endures her mother's bullying and her daughter's coming out on top of her divorce, plus being used by her estranged husband while he is also seeing her therapist who she had been paying to help her sort out her problems.  {Ewww)  Goldie Hawn is an actress who, in an industry which glorifies youth and beauty unlike any other, had her husband leave her for a younger woman even though she has pulled her face taught and self medicating with alcohol rather than popping pain pills. Women have a fear of being overthrown based on their age, of getting dried up and loosing their attractiveness.  Then, when their husbands / boyfriends get tired of them they will be inevitably traded in for younger women.  Why?  There is no one answer to this.  Greed, a realization of one's own mortality, the proverbial "midlife crisis" situation, physical attractiveness or unattractiveness all play a role.  There is no real answer. In 1996, Hugh Wilson directed a very funny comedy about three friends that were all dumped by their husbands for younger women in the film "First Wives Club".  Based upon the 1992 novel of the same name by Olivia Goldsmith (1949-2004), the three friends (who had met in college) are brought back together after their fourth friend, Cynthia Swann Griffin (Stockard Channing), jumped from her penthouse apartment in Manhattan after her husband left and she felt totally alone.  Upon learning about each others similar marital problems, the surviving friends, which include the boisterous Brenda Cushman (Bette Midler), the movie actress Elise Elliot (Goldie Hawn) and the timid Annie Paradis (Diane Keaton), decide to work together to attain vengence upon their ex-husbands.  Brenda's ex-husband, Morton 'Morty' Cushman (Dan Hedaya), wants to marry the very young and shallow Shelly Stewart (Sarah Jessica Parker).  Elise's ex-husband, Bill Atchison (Victor Garber), is dating the very young aspiring actress Phoebe LaVelle (Elizabeth Berkley).  Annie's separated husband, Aaron Paradis (Stephen Collins), is having an affair with Annie's therapist, Dr. Leslie Rosen (Marcia Gay Harden).  To assist them, the trio of first wives enlist help from their friends, which include the interior decorator Duarto Feliz (Bronson Pinchot), Annie's daughter Chris Paradis (Jennifer Dundas), the socialite Gunilla Garson Goldberg (Maggie Smith) and Brenda's Uncle Carmine (Philip Bosco).
Though the plot was somewhat weak and the acting and screen writing were not Oscar-worthy, "First Wives Club" is still very entertaining and engaging.  The most memorable acting comes from Goldie Hawn, Bette Midler, Diane Keaton, Sarah Jessica Parker and Victor Garber.  The film did receive an Oscar nomination for Best Original Score.  Memorable scenes in the film include Cynthia on her balcony, her funeral, the trio at the restaurant, Elise visiting Bill's office, Annie's visits with Dr. Leslie Rosen, Morty's commercial, Shelly with Gunilla, Morty's apartment, the auction, the fight, Annie's purchase, Chris' announcement and the closing scenes.  Other memorable characters include Annie's mother Catherine MacDuggan (Eileen Heckart, 1919-2001), Dr. Morris Packman (Rob Reiner) and Brenda's son Jason (Ari Greenberg), as well as cameos by Ivana Trump, Kathie Lee Gifford, Gloria Steinem and former NYC mayor Edward I. Koch.  Olivia Goldsmith also made an unaccredited cameo.  Overall, I rate "First Wives Club" with 4 out of 5 stars.  It's a fun film that both women and men can enjoy, though women may enjoy it more since the men in the film are the bad guys.

First of all, allow me to say one thing:  I am sick of people only writing reviews of the movies they really love.  It is possible to write BAD reviews as well folks....in fact, it's much more fun than writing good ones.  Think of some movies you really hate, then go and rip into them with a scathing review.  It's therapeutic!
Now on to this wretched movie.  I'll say right off the bat that I was biased against this movie before I even saw it, for several reasons:  I don't like Bette Midler, Diane Keaton, or Goldie Hawn - the three of them together have about as much talent as an arthritic flea.  Also, I don't like this genre - the sort of movies where womankind is portrayed as being the most powerful force on Earth, and nothing, least of all a scurvy, double-dealing MAN, can stop it.  And ladies wonder where the term "feminazi" came from - movies like this! BUT - even putting aside all my ill feelings, I STILL dind't like this movie, just because it has what is literally one of the worst casts ever assembled for a big-budget Hollywood picture, and so therefore the acting is horrid; the writing is devilishly bad, and the direction is third-rate.  Finally, and most importantly - the movie never made me believe that the husbands did anything so nasty that they deserved to be subjected to the dispicable acts of revenge perpetrated upon them by their ex-wives.  So they cheated on their wives - big deal!  It happens every day all over the world, and anyone who can't accept it to the degree that they feel the need to resort to sickening acts of vengeance needs to be institutionalized.  What the wives do to the husbands is far, far, far worse than what the husbands do to the wives - thus, you lose any sympathy the movie wants you to feel for the heroines and you end up leaving depressed by the fact that these hapless dames just ran a royal screw-job over these poor saps and they are gonna get away scott-free.  This isn't a "feel good" movie at all - it is a saddening indictment of the calamities that result when "girl power" is taken to the ultimate extremes.  Shame on the cast, shame on the crew, and shame on any and all who enjoyed this dreck called "The First Wives Club".
